Freakies

Frankies

By MURPHY CLAWS
My gazebo floated ever closer
to the fair pavement, when I saw
the man with the ebony
mustache motioning for me to
come to him. He became much
larger, until I could see his black
vest, white suit and cane. The
white cane reminded me that it
was the same man who watched
me put mustard on my
crabcakes, and he had warned me
not to put on too much. And
then I was sure it was the very
same man who had made some
sort of gesture to me at the
carnival entrance.
His image blurred into the
crowd as the ferris wheel drew
me under and up, above the
booths and the restaurant
rotating on its space needle.
Hurriedly I scanned the melee, but
with no luck. I couldn't wait for
the ride to finish, so I could
investigate who this man was and
what he wanted from me; but the
ferris wheel was sweeping faster
and faster, it seemed, and I
wasn't sure if I would ever see
that ebony mustache again, or
what I would say if I did.
Each time I circled, the ground
showed no sign of him.
Later, dawdling down the
fairway, stuffing cotton candy in
my face, which gave me a pink
mustache, he appeared in the
doorway of a display. The cane
flashed in the sun as the man
With the ebony mustache
stretched the canvas high above
me so that I might pass before
him into the tent.
I saw a crowd of people
shuffling through hay, looking
into stalls; muffled sounds of
horses or maybe baboons
were projected towards me
through the din of the gay
crowd.
Was I being solicited or merely
entertained? This had become all
too curious—I decided to stride
well ahead of my guide, and
snaked through all the
pandemonium of a political
convention and toward the
corner booth. On a tasteful
platform, there were albino
siamese twins, a delightful pair,
Sipping tea. Chattily, they
Whispered completely
undisturbed by the taunts flung
at them by a gang of suckling
boys. I felt the cane press the
small of my back.
"They love the Haydn, the
tea's for free, and for two
hundred bucks they couldn't
turn it down. Look what else I
have here my boy."
I whirled to face him. "Show
Your hand, you seem to think
You're dealer here," I demanded,
not appreciating his pointed
introduction.
"I have a goat boy who eats
too much hay, my fish woman
needs her tank cleaned; the grey
haired boy in the center smokes
too many cigars. You know they
formed a union today. Sport, the
skeleton of the Java woman cost
me a fortune in the bidding war
With, the museum and the plane
fare for the gorilla man with the
bluest hair in the northern
hemisphere cost me a fortune.
But I have a space for you."

By TEX 'WIENER.

Presenting Baltimore City Fair
By GAYLE COHEN
More than two million persons
will get together this weekend to
have fun and pay tribute to
Baltimore. The occasion is the
seventh annual Baltimore City
Fair, which begins today and
runs through Sunday night.
The festivities take place just
west of the newly-refurbished
Inner Harbor, with the port and
the downtown business district
acting as a scenic backdrop.
Entertainment will be
provided nonstop on each of the
fair's five stages. Headliners
include singer Joe Williams at 8
p.m. Friday, bandleader Benny
Goodman at 8 p.m. Saturday,
and drummer Buddy Rich at 8
p.m. Sunday. Specialty acts will
be presented on the
country-western, ethnic, and
children's stages.
The food selection will also
run the gamut from the
traditional standbys to the wildly
exotic. Several ethnic
organizations will sell native
delicacies, and the conventional
Maryland crabcakes and beer will
abound.
Despite its loose appearance,
the fair serves a serious purpose.
As Lannie Taliaserro of the fair's
Coordinating Council explained,
"Our philosophy has always been
to focus on the vitality of
Baltimore as an urban center. It's
the onl fair of its kind, and it

was brought into being to point
up that Baltimore is not dead."
In keeping with this attitude,
the fair stresses individual arid
community involvement. For
example, almost all of the more
than 7,000 workers are
volunteers. Their dedication
stems from pride in Baltimore
and their neighborhoods.
Randall Shaull, chairman of
the Irvington booth, commented
on the fair's importance. "Since
World War II, the world has been
used to transiency. People just
move. They don't take advantage
of their city. I have to have a
positive viewpoint. If I didn't feel
this way, I wouldn't be in this
business."
Shaull's booth is only one of
75 neighborhood display stalls
designed by community groups
to promote their areas. The
Irvington booth will feature a
large cartoon-style map of the
section, a residential region in the
southwest. A collage of
photographs will display
neighborhood landmarks and
historical material. The
important idea, according to
Shaull, "is to keep it
non-commercial, fresh, and
appealing."
Gene Ruckle, coordinator of
the Greater Homewood booth,
hopes that his booth serves as "a
guide to the Greater Homewood
Area and its services." A slide

Have you ever been insulted
when someone calls you a Hot
Dog? Well, Nick Daskalakis gets
called hot dog for a living and he
doesn't mind it one bit.
Out of the endless stream of
immigrants pouring across from
the Old Country in anticipation
of streets paved with gold, the
affable Greek instead discovered
hot-dog-roll lined boulevards here
in Charm City. "Polish people are
the champion hot dog eaters," he
mused, and everyone knows that
Baltimore has more than its share
of Polish descendants.
Nick has been serving up red
hot wieners at the City Fair for
the past four years. Not only has
he acquired the reputation for
being a master vendor, he also
acquired his lovely wife who
refused to be named. "I am
fascinated by the coincidence
that the year after I met my wife
at the fair, over a beer no less, we
returned to the Inner Harbor in
hopes of peddling our hot dogs,"
he elaborated.

show entitled People Are The
Key and a "Put Your Block On
The Map" exhibit will highlight
the Greater Homewood display.
Nearly 110 non-profit
institutions will also operate
exhibits. Some of the
participants in this category are
The Johns Hopkins University,
the Enoch Pratt Free Library, the
Legal Aid Bureau, Planned
Parenthood, and the YMCA.
The money for the fair's
expenses comes primarily from
business donations raised by the
City Fair Board. A spokesman
fof the fair's Coordinating
Council said, "Our general hope
is to break even. Last year we
made a slight profit so we sent
some youngsters to the Maryland
Junior Olympics for handicapped
children."
Helping others is what the City
Fair is all about. So,for a chance
to do just that while
simultaneously eating Italian
food and watching Polish dances
and honoring Charm City, visit
the fair.
Fair hours are Friday, 11:30
a.m.-10 p.m.; Saturday, 10
a.m.-10 p.m.; and Sunday,
noon-10 p.m. Shuttle buses will
leave for the fairgrounds from
the Wyman Park Drive parking
lot every 20 minutes Saturday
One would think it takes a lot
and Sunday, beginning at 10 a.m. of
ingenuity to calculate the
Admission is $1.25 at the gate. number of hot
dogs needed to
Shuttle bus fare is 50 cents.
feed the ravishing hordes at the
ty Fair."y,"says the Grecian
gourmet. They've replaced the
brain with a systemized system
designed to accurately and
acutely eliminate previous and
costly inaccuracies in
determining the hot dogs, per
capita. But not lost in this
"devaluation of the frank" is the
tender geniality of the Aegean
Adonis. "We like all our
customers, but especially families
of ten," he slyly admitted.
Queried about his method of
service, the Athenian epicure
replied that "we use the French
method. I grab the little dog with
tongs, and place it between the
embracing halves of a
passionately yearning virgin hot
dog roll."
"And if the customer desires
mustard, mustard it will be. And
it gladdens my heart to see him
eat it with relish."
"Perhaps Freud was right;
sometimes a hot dog is just a hot
dog."

Dylan for Dollars

page 2/news-letter/september 17, 1976

Is the wind still blowing:A voice ac/es amid the dead

•

By DAVID HAWK
As every rock magazine from
here to Hibbing has testified, Bob
Dylan is a living legend.
Unfortunately, even such
larger-than-life figures can blow
it, as Tuesday night's Dylan
special (Hard Rain) bears out.
The live performance, taped in
Colorado, was a disappointment,
as even the most fanatical
Dylanite would be forced to
admit.
Although just seeing Dylan live
was a thrill, and even though it
was his first commercial
television special, Dylan's
somewhat tuneless gargling, the
antics of the other members of
the Rolling Thunder Revue, and
the questionable quality of the
music left one unsatisfied.
"A Hard Rain's A-Gonna Fall"
was perhaps the best selection in
the show, and was the first
performed. All the songs would
appeal to hard-core Dylan
people, but one got the
discomforting impression that
they could have and had been
done better. "Idiot Wind", the
final number, was the nadir, as
Dylan slipped into the
monotonous forced singing
which characterizes Before the
Flood. The preceding pieces were
more tunefully done, but these
fell into two categories: the
acoustic songs, on which Dylan
and Baez usually colloborated,
holding the verses to unnatural
lengths while the camera nearly
poked them in the head; and the
more electric versions, on which
the Revue paused while Dylan
fired out a line, and then plunged
back into a pattern of repetitive
and uninspiring accompaniment.
Perhaps the way the songs
were done was excusable, even
though the performance doesn't
compare to Dylan's May 1966
Dublin concert, but TV Guide's
promotional blurb ironically
pointed up Hard Rain's most
important and frustrating
inadequacies. The show was
billed as a portrait of Dylan, a
"multi-faceted view," a
performance demonstrating that
Dylan has justifiably been
interpreted and acclaimed as "a
teacher, revolutionary, firebrand,
messiah, mystic, prophet." The
view was hardly multi-faceted,
unless you term alternation
between two camera angles as
multi-faceted. The show
obsfucated the "real" Dylan, if it
did anything at all in terms ,of a
personal portrait. To pretend
that the performance revealed
Dylan as a prophet, mystic, et
cetera is absurd. What did Hard
Rain accomplish in terms of
explicating Dylan in any sense?
Little if anything. It is extremely
unfortunate that the appearance,
ballyhooed as it was, was so
poorly organized and executed,
and so successful in disguising his
genius.
That Dylan has been one of
the single most important forces
in popular music few will deny.
In the tumultuous sixties, he
captured the spiritual restlessness
of American youth with a force,
vision, and clarity which has
never been equalled.
Unquestionably, this is the key

to his success and the essence of
his brilliance: Dylan is most of all
an emotional genius ("How does
it fe-e-e-e-e-1??"). Despite the
less-than-lustrous quality of his
voice, and his imperfect musical
ability, Dylan has become
famous on the strength of his
knack for articulating the
frustrations, needs, and problems
of his generation.
But the juxtaposition of
Dylan's greatness and his grating
TV-special debut point up what
is probably the most pressing
issue concerning the Voice of the
sixties: Is the Dylan of that
turbulent era merely a pitiful
anachronism in the seventies,
hanging onto a reputation built
ten years ago? Or can the
25-year-old who set the
American consciousness
throbbing with "A Hard Rain's
A-Gonna Fall," "Blowin' in the
Wind," "Like a Rolling Stone,"
and Blonde on Blonde "speak"
again at the hoary age of 35?
Bob Dylan and the nineteen
sixties are inseparable, the mood
and the man so a part of each
other, from the Missile Crisis to
Berkeley ("Who can separate the
dancer from the dance?"). DyIgn
asked the questions that
America's youth felt but could
not articulate ("OH, mama, can
this really be the end. . .?-), and,
avoiding soothing answers, bared
the naked agony of his soul, and
ripped away the veil, standing
unwound beneath the sky on
clouds unbound by law, in a
soldier's stance aiming his hand
at the mongrel dogs who taught.

perhaps feeling too much for too
many, and now he who has
always led the way must decide
whether there is anywhere else to
go.
After the musical brilliance of
the sixties, which was coupled
with a rare sense of social
consciousness, the seventies haye
been marked by a chilling
descent into the sugary
empty-headed optimism of John
Denver and Olivia Newton-John
and the convoluted clanking of
such entries as Led Zeppelin,
Kiss, and the LA. Death Trip,
not to mention the usual top-40
sillylovesongs syndrome. The
Grateful Dead and The Rolling
Stones hang on with nothing left,
and groups like Quicksilver
Messenger Service and the
erstwhile-Jefferson Airplane roll
over in their once-respectable
graves and attempt to fill the gap.
Perhaps Dylan has been caught in
the post-sixties malaise of
mediocrity and big-bucks
strategems, his thought-dreams
disintegrating, his watchtower
left abandoned, as the wind
howling still louder in the
deafening silence, yet unheard.
Money talks, Dylan walks
4L L THAT JAZZ
In the past few years some of the best concerts have been sponsored by the city government. Last year's City Fair
presented Maynard Ferguson, as well as Dave Brubeck and Sons. Last summer's free On Stage Downtown series
included three jazz concerts: Maynard Ferguson, Lionel Hampton, and Charlie Byrd. This year's City Fair (Sept. 17, 18,
19) will have some local jazz groups on the minor stages, but the big concerts are all on Stage One. These concerts are
included in the $1,25 entrance fee to the fairgrounds (Inner Harbor West). Today, Al Baitch is scheduled at 3:30 p.m.,
and Joe Williams at 8 p.m. On Saturday the Jimmy Wells Quintet will play at 4:30 p.m., and Benny Goodman brings
back the memories at 8 p.m. Hank Levy's Towson State Jazz Ensemble will perform on Sunday at 3p.m., with Buddy
Rich scheduled to play at 8 p.m.

But the sixties are gone
forever, the times are not
changing as they once were, and
disillusionment no longer has
even poignance. With the end of
the decade came the end of
Dylan's vision, or so it would
seem. John Wesley Harding,
which came out in January of
1968, appears to mark the end of
Dylan's most brilliant periods.
Excluding the official release of
The Basement Tapes in the
summer of 1975, ten Dylan
albums have been released since
John Wesley Harding, and even
the best of these cannot come up
to his previous work. The
urgency is gone, an intangible has
been lost, and even though Dylan
addicts don't know how to quit,
there must lurk for them the fear
that he in some sense has.
Now it looks as if Dylan is
going on, writing good music
where he once wrote great music,
building a ten million dollar
mansion in California, replacing
the aesthetics of vision with the
economics of self-enrichment.
Dylan said one time that he
would rather die than decay. In a
recent TV Guide interview he
claimed that he is writing new
music, trying new things.
However, the suspicion is that
Dylan is indeed decaying. No,
maybe he was right—maybe he's
already dead.
In any case, Dylan's position
has never been an easy one. He
went through the harassment and
scrutiny which accompany being
acclaimed as a seer, he
experienced the excruciation of

The sun also looms on other horizons
By DAVE COPELAND
Sun rising over Goucher
College. To many Hopkins males,
the memory, or anticipation, of
such a sight connotes the glories
of a one-night conquest, or
Perhaps a lasting undergraduate
affair.
To me, sun rising over
Goucher College was a sight I
could barely see, for the sunlight
burst so glaringly through the
windows that it blinded me
Whenever I looked outside. It was
eight a.m. on a December
morning last winter. I sat quietly
in the Goucher Library, intently
Porin g over Smirnitsky's
R ussian -English Dictionary,
struggling by rote, rather than by
understanding, to translate forty
Russian sentences into at least
mediocre English. The task
before me was the completion of
three weeks worth of overdue
assignments by early afternoon,
all for the purpose of attaining a
"B". And the incentive? The
grade would probably make or
break my chances for the Dean's
List that semester. The professor
was from Goucher, and so the
assignment had to be delivered to
her office in Van Meter Hall. It
had seemed as reasonable a
venture as any to accomplish my
task that morning at Goucher
Library. The notion appealed to
my sense of the romantically
absurd.
had never expected, however,
the total desolation I experienced
as soon as I arrived.
Everyone
had gone: gone home to their
parents somewhere in American
Suburbia.
What was left was a
campus that can be staggering in
its sheer
beauty—this wide
exPanse of open, rolling land
Only minimally violated by
scattered two-level halls
of
a
cademia. Now that beauty had
become more powerful, more
n minous, by virtue of its
unpeopled state, and the dry,
biting winter cold that swept
across campus.
I sat, read, referred, and wrote
for two hours. My two study
breaks consisted of finding and
relocating the men's room in the
basement. I was half done.
D ecidin g that this was
undoubtably a watershed in my
efforts, I rose and
walked over to
a book rack by the couches,
Where I spied, then seized a copy
of Hugh Kenner's T.S. Eliot: The
Invisible Poet. I had just finished
taking Kenner's "Yeats Pound,
and Eliot" course
that semester.
Despite having done virtually no
Lw°rk in the course,I had "gotten
uY.

_written the year before. As I

InY Russian notebooks,
and then

risen, and no longer glared), I

had been concerned with
for a

Of course, I hadn't timed my
departure at all with the shuttle
leaving Goucher. A vacant face in
the switchboard booth at
Stimson Hall told me that the
next bus arrived in half an hour.
So I lumbered back to Van
Meter, sat out on the steps for
twenty-five minutec, and froze. It
never occurred to me to wait
inside.
The semester dragged on for
another four days, with two
all-nighters. I then made a quick
escape to New York City.
Of six grades, four were
test -case borderline. They all
went the right way; I made the
Dean's List.
Next term, the apathy
increased. "Getting by" now
consisted of attending classes on
an intermittent basis, and living
in a room that was decorated
early- Armageddon.
My need for some form of an
active existence was quickly
sated with the development of a
few intriguing personal
relationships. There was a vivid
sense within me that I should
somehow go beyond that, but I
lacked the motivation, or
possibly the fortitude, to do so.
Controversies
On campus, controversies
raged. I signed a petition
protesting the honorary degree
bestowed upon the Princess
Ashraf of Iran, and donated fifty
cents for the privilege of wearing
a bracelet which celebrated the
cause of one Iranian political
prisoner. Within the day, the
sweat on my wrist had caused the
ink to run. The legibility of the
inscription dissolved, and with it
any fleeting personal sense of
.social awareness.
In late January, prior to the
Ashraf incident, the editor of the
News-Letter began pestering me
to write a major feature on
Hopkins' takeover of the
Baltimorean Hotel. What was
wanted was a human interest
nerloot

npnnlp

apttina

evicted) and an analysis of the

-11•111111,1C"

town-gown situation. Recent
editorials in the News-Letter had
come out strongly against
University expansion.
Myself, among others, doubted
the feasibility of this story as a
feature—whether it was there to
be written.
Yet it was a week in which I
could think of nothing better to
do. I took the story. It occurred
to me that I might end up almost
having to invent angles. But my
frame of mind had evolved to the
point where such idealistic goals
as "total journalistic integrity"
seemed irrelevant in terms of
pursuable or desirable
achievements.
The feature that I wrote on
the Baltimorean did not contain
one single untruth, misquotation,
or any other overt indication of
spurious journalism. What it did
contain was a series of
manipulated scenes, and
conversations that were
consciously overblown and
underblown to suit the tone of
the article. Of greatest
consequence were an elderly
switchboard operator who
divided her attention equally
between myself and the ABC late
night special, and my next door
neighbor (I live right near the
Baltimorean), who was just full
of quotable truisms about
"longhairs" from Hopkins, and
how they hurt the neighborhood.
Suffice it to say that I wrote an
article which, however imperfect
stylistically, provided excellent
fodder for an "outraged"
editorial decrying Hopkins'
repeated violations of the
surrounding community.
None of which bothered me.
My own view of the situation was
passively pragmatic. I saw
Hopkins as the heavyweight, who
had the sheer brute strength to
beat up on the lightweight
community organizations
virtually at will. I also perceived
such bullying tactics as
essentially a mistake, and any
positive steps taken to improve
town-gown relations (which was

being done at the time) as being
highly desirable. My thinking was
that eventually Hopkins was
going to encounter a situation
that necessitated some form of
University expansion, over which
the community had total veto
power, by virtue of a strict
zoning law, or the like. And if at
that time the Greater Homewood
Community Corporation had
experienced nothing but being
pushed around,they would never
give in.
I saw nothing inherently venal
in the purchase of the
Baltimorean, which had been
obtained for the purpose of
housing graduate studentc
nudged out of McCoy by
undergraduates. But to the
extent that the property had
been usurped from the
community, and not bargained
for, the operation had been a
diplomatic blunder.
So what? My opinion. Never
expressed in the feature, and so
of no consequence. After all, I
had written the story they had
told me to write. I had gotten by.
That's all that matters. Right?
Then Faulkner (a la A Rose
For Emily) came to North
Charles Street. A fifty year old
woman named Ann Baker had
been living in near-total seclusion
for thirteen years, seen only by
her priest and by a delivery man
from the Greenway Pharmacy.
She was a recluse, living only
with room-high piles of garbage.
And she didn't want to leave. So
when she was told that she had
to go, she feigned acquiensence,
and then lit the garbage with a
match. And Ann Baker died.
The next day the News-Letter
came out with a lead article on
Ann Baker's death accompanied
by an angry, vindictive editorial.
The pieces combined to imply
one simple statement: Hopkins
killed Ann Baker.
I was stunned. The conclusion
was specious. For this reason:
Ann Baker predetermined her
own death. Thirteen years
before, she had carefully begun

to construct an existence which
could never have tolerated
exposure to the external world.
Hopkins' eviction did force the
crisis, and so the suicide (her one
alternative for an absolute
rebellion against reality). But the
crisis probably would have been
forced anyway, by some other
agency, because THE
BALTIMOREAN WAS FOR
SALE. It is a definite possibility
that WHOEVER had bought that
building might have evicted Ann
Baker. And so killed her?
One can only guess at the
reasoning of the News-Letter
staff. It seems legitimate to say,
however, that the Ann Baker
editorial was • just a natural
consequence of the continuing
series of articles and editorials
concerning the Baltimorean. And
the longest, and perhaps most
widely read of those articles. ..
I wrote.
And hadn't believed in.
And had written anyway.
Just to get by.
In righteous anger, I decided
to fire off an angry response to
the editors. I never did.
Since then, the issue has died,
in a manner somewhat quieter
than the death of Ann Baker.
To me, however, there is a
different issue, one that has little
to do with Hopkins housing,
town-gown politics, or whatever.
It is an issue which has not died
in my mind.
The issue is the reconstruction
of one's frame of mind, to the
point where it can be resolved:
" I will not spend this life
'getting by."
The issue is the need to
awaken to what is around you. If
the Hopkins existence is to be a
legitimate one,it cannot be spent
ignoring three-quarters of the
university because, "Why should
I care. . .", "I don't fit in with
that. ..","Those people couldn't
care about me. ..","The girls on
this campus are too obnoxious. .
.", "The boys on this campus
can't accept intelligent women. .
.", "Yeah, philosophy's
rnterestmg, but it's bullshit, and
besides it won't help me get into
med school..."
Forfeit
How many have loved physics,
but no longer think about it,just
blindly take notes and memorize,
just to get by? How many never
listen to a professor who actually
has something to say, or worse
yet, don't even make an effort to
take courses with those
professors?
How many have spent most of
their career at Hopkins
consciously forfeiting the
opportunity to learn?
The school year has begun
once more, my third year ai
Hopkins. For the first time, I am
awake. I make an effort, perhaps
visibly the effort of a neophyte,
to communicate with individuals
throughout the Hopkins
spectrum (and beyond), to
experience, to soak in, to try to
understand, to reach a critical
comprehension of, all that I see.
And I try to see as much as I can.
To the extent that I have
achieved these goals so far, the
question, "Where is my life
going?" no longer grates on my

mao
Last night approximately one hundred people
gathered in
the Clipper Room of Shriver Hall to participate.in a memorial
service for the great, fallen Chinese leader, Chairman
Mao
Tse-Tung. At the service, Mao, who died last week at the
age
of 82, was the subject of numerous tributes and
expressions
of admiration and thanks for the tremendous
revolutionary
change through which he helped guide the Chinese people
in
the last sixty years.
A central feature of Mao's life was his
constant,
unwavering dedication to serving his Chinese countryme
n.
Theoretician, statesman, military leader, and educator were
but some of the forms this service took. Although the
has been long, difficult and not without mistakes, road
even
Western observers must admit that the quality of life in
China
has been dramatically upgraded under Mao's leadershi
.

But in the end, Mao wanted to be remembered primarily as
a teacher. Perhaps more than any other modern figure, Mao
was able to communicate a dynamic, integrated
understanding of how the world works and how people can
change it. While most of his theories and accomplishments
run counter to the American ethic, they are well worth
considering in light of the tremendous influence they have
exerted on people throughout the world. And perhaps more
than anything else, Mao should be bailed for illustrating that
a betterment of the human condition need not be an idle,
utopian dream, but, through a common, sustained effort, can
become gratifying reality.

Captain Bligh

The University:for whose end?
We need a sense of morality
By MARK HERTSGAARD
"What is this university supposed to
be?"
After more than a week of
"orientation", the same conversations
(where you from, what's your major,
what are you taking, etc.), and official
welcomes from university luminaries
of various intensities, that question, or
variations of it, has probably been
pondered by many a freshman.
Although perhaps to a lesser extent,
upperclassmen may be considering the
same query as they come progressively
closer to graduation. Seniors can
hardly avoid the matter since
everyone they talk to asks the
inevitable question regarding their
plans after leaving Hopkins. Of course,
the answer depends largely on what a
senior has already done at this
university and how well it has met
his/her needs.
At the root of most of the
challenges against the traditionalist
view of the university has been the
disturbing realization that a college
education no longer assures a
good
job" in today's society. In her book,
The Case Against College, Caroline
Bird argues that many high school
graduates can fare better financially
by going to work and saving the
thousands of would-be tuition dollars.
In the face of such criticism. Johns
Hopkins President Steven Muller has
called for the goals of American
universities to be reoriented toward
higher learning and away from mere
higher skilling. While preparation for
future jobs would still remain a
fixture of the college years, the
primary purpose of university
instruction and study must be to
produce graduates who are highly
educated.
Of course, the role of the university
is always partly determined by the
constraints of the society in which it
exists. The purposes of universities in
1976 America differ markedly from
those of colonial times when
institutions of higher education
produced mainly clergy and teachers.
Colleges and universities by and large
remained establishments reserved for
the intellectually and socially elite
well into the tweatieth century. But
around the time of World Vvar II, and
corresponding to the ever increasing
needs for educated, technical
personnel to run the rapidly
developing American economy, higher
education began to be democratized.
The numbers of college students and,
consequently, also their diversity in
terms of race and class,nottceably
increased. The university began to be
perceived as an institution that
pumped out the graduates necessary
to keep America moving forward in
the modern age.

As Alvin Toffler wrote in Future
Shock, "Mass education was the
ingenious machine constructed by
industrialism to produce the kind of
adults it needed to run industrial
society. . .Yet the whole idea of
assembling masses of students (raw
material) to be processed by teachers
(workers) in a centrally located school
(factory) was a stroke of industrial
genius." Although Toffler was writing
in regard to the time period of the
Industrial Revolution, the parallels to
today are obvious. In fact, much of
the student protest of the 1960's was
directed against the regimentation,
alienation and authoritarianism of
higher education and the society
which it reflected.
Now, as we move through the
1970's, it is more common for
students to question the purposes of
higher education in more
self-centered, career oriented terms.
Will it give me a better job? Is it worth
all that money?
It is exceedingly important for us
to remember that views on the
purpose and the role of the university
greatly depend on one's perspective
on and relationship to it. Rest assured
that a rising student politico's and a
pre-med's views differ substantially
and that their difference is small when
compared to that between a staff
custodian and a university trustee.
Consider als9 the contrast between
how major corporations and
community residents conceive of
universities and their members.
In spite of these individual
differences, the world of academia is
still permeated by the comfortable.
conventional view of the role of the
university. The university is seen as a
center of culture, free thinking and
independent, oective research and
instruction. The uni•
:s
sometimes considered to
„ sort of
enlightened, benevolent servant who
earns his keep in society by helping us
better to understand and confront the
world and by tackling the tough
problems that impede human
progress.
In judging the aptness of this
description, two suggestions may
prove helpful. First, in making any
social judgment, perhaps the most
useful questions to ask are: who is
hurt, who is helped, how, and why?
Second, the judgments again depend
largely on whose perspective (e.g.,
student, faculty or society) is
considered.
For the well-directed, career
oriented undergrad, Johns Hopkins
provides one of the finest educations
in the country; that is, the JHU
education will help its recipient along
the road to grad school, a respectable,
and perhaps even interesting, job, and
ultimately to American success. But
before lauding Hopkins on this
accomplishment, we must consider
the nature of this success. In this
context, success can be seen as
implying the wealth, prestige and
security that usually accompany
upper middle class existence. But
what about the notion of service to
society? Is an M.D. degree to be
viewed as an unofficial license to print
money or rather as an opportunity to
serve society in a special capacity?
While students participate almost
exclusively in the second of the
university's major functions, as the
recipients of teaching, professors
engage in both teaching and research.
At Hopkins, the professors most
esteemed by the university are those
who bring fame and prestige (and,
therefore, plenty of research funds) to
Hopkins; i.e., the well renowned
research scholars. Some of these men
and women are also fine, dedicated
educators, a happy combination for
all concerned. Some are not. But for
those faculty members who do not
excel in the "publish of perish" game,
receiving tenure is almost impossible if
he/she is judged by colleagues in the
academic world not to be in the top
twenty percent in his/her field. This
priority of research over teaching
clearly has negative ramifications on
the quality of instruction at Hopkins.

But we must probe beyond these
ramifications to try to determine what
this priority says about the nature of
Johns Hopkins and other universities.
It indicates that the primary allegiance
of the university and many of its
faculty must be toward the kind of
research that will attract substantial
grant monies. A research project or an
innovative program cannot be run if
no funds are available. And what kind
of research fits this definition? Often,
and obviously, it must be the kind
that will serve those wealthy and
powerful interests (big corporations,
the government, etc.) who can afford
to sponsor it. This should not be seen
as surprising. How reasonable is it to
expect that profit-conscious
organizations will squander money on
research that is of little or no use to
them?
These practices and relationships
have very definite implications on
how and who the university serves in
its cotnmunity and society. To
continue to exist, a primary concern
of Johns Hopkins and other
universities must be to stay in the
good graces of the rich and powerful.
The conducting of research that serves
those interests is a major, but not the
only, tool at the disposal of a
university. These priorities, which
dictate that much of the research in
American universities be oriented
toward such areas as weapons
development rather than projects that
will help those most in need, are
similar to those that cause the
government to spend a
disproportionate amount of national
defense at the expense of rural health
services. The challenging by
universities of this "them that has.
gits" status quo is not encouraged.
This is not meant to imply that a
university performs no useful
functions. Nor should one get the
impression that university, corporate
and governmental officials spend all
their waking hours plotting to exploit
the poor. Such ‘Tiotild be an
insensitive, shallow and naive
judgement. Qn the contrary, there are
many instances when useful services
have been performed by people within
the university. I3ut in aggregate, no

mistaken judgement can be made. A
university cannot serve two masters
and, when forced to choose, cannot
afford to bite the hand that feeds it.
Some may counter this line of
reasoning with the argument (often
heard during last year's Iranian
demonstrations) that a university
must play this unfortunate game if it
is to remain solvent. That's the way
the system is, the way the world
operates. If the university is to exist
and hope to serve society, it must
sometimes accept money for some
research activities that are ethically
questionable. Such people sometimes
even admit that this practice cheapens
the integrity of the university, but
would consider it to be a necessary
evil that is traded off against the good
that the urliversity can do. This
counter-argument is correct in one
very important point—yes, the system,
the constraints of modern, Western
society, does demand that universities
perform this way. However, this
argument errs by limply accepting
these practices as regrettable
necessities rather than questioning the
morality and legitimacy of the system
that produces them.

The 1977-78 competition for grants
for graduate study abroad offered
under the Mutual Educational
Exchange Program (Fulbright-Hays).
and by foreign governments,
universities and private donors will
close shortly. Only a few more weeks
remain in which qualified graduate
students may apply for one of the 550
awards which are available to 54
countries.
Most of the grants offered provide
round-trip transportation, tuition and
maintenance for one academic year; a
few provide international travel only
or a stipend intended as a partial
grant-in-aid.
Candidates must be U.S. citizens at
the time of application, hold a
bachejor's degree or its equivalent by
the beginning date of the grant, have
language ability commensurate with
the demands of the proposed study
projects, and good health. Aspirants
should contact Dr. Dierman.
Hurry! Sign up before it's too late!

purpose of the course will be to
introduce students to the American
ethic and religious anthropology in
the development of contemporary
American society."
The course meets on Monday,
Tuesday and Wednesday at 11:00 a.m.
and it is for three credits. No course is
as good as the prospectus
suggests—except this one.

Booters impressive in GW loss
By ANDREW COHEN
Plagued by three key offensive
injuries, the Johns Hopkins
soccer team was blanked, 1-0, by
a strong team from George
Washington University in their
final preseason clash.
The only goal of the game
came late in the first half when a
Blue Jay penalty allowed George
Washington to cash in on a direct
kick.
Although they lost, the Blue
Jay squad looked very impressive
on defense against the well
disciplined offense of GW. The
opponent maintained excellent
ball control throughout the
game, thereby calling the Jay's
defense to meet the challenge.
In the first half a George
Washington break away was
halted by the quick hands of a
.11-1U fullback who pulled down
the potential scorer. When the
oPponent failed on the penalty
oPportunity the Blue Jays were
out of trouble. Later in the
second half it was goalie Ken
Suesse who stopped a GW threat
by just tipping away another
beautifully placed direct kick.
With the big opening game
against Haverford only a few
days away, Coach Bob Oliver
thought it wise to rest his starting
offensive line trio of Greg
C unningham, Larry
McGowan,

and Hyam Levin. Without this
extra scoring punch in the lineup
it was difficult for the JHUers to
generate any offensive threats,
though they did muster a few.
About a quarter of the way
into the second half the Blue
Jays were able to put pressure on
the George Washington goal
tender. Some unnecessary
dramatics on the part of the GW
goalie allowed the ball to squirt
loose in front of the net and if it
hadn't been for the experienced
feet of the GW defenders, the
Jays would have found
themselves right back in the
ballgame.
On another occasion lineman
Joe Siemek was able to gain
control of the loose ball and send
a looping shot right on net. The
GW goalie was able to recover
just in time in order to bat away
the potential goal.
JHU's last scoring opportunity
came with only seconds left in
the game. Gary Ignatowski was
fed a beautiful slide pass that left
him ten yards out, one on one
against the goalie. But again the
Jays were turned away by a
pretty save.
Coach Oliver was pleased with
this final game as he was with the
entire soccer preseason.
According to him his entire
substitution bench showed poise

Freakies

Frankies

By MURPHY CLAWS
My gazebo floated ever closer
to the fair pavement, when I saw
the man with the ebony
mustache motioning for me to
come to him. He became much
larger, until I could see his black
vest, white suit and cane. The
white cane reminded me that it
was the same man who watched
me put mustard on my
crabcakes, and he had warned me
not to put on too much. And
then I was sure it was the very
same man who had made some
sort of gesture to me at the
carnival entrance.
His image blurred into the
crowd as the ferris wheel drew
me under and up, above the
booths and the restaurant
rotating on its space needle.
Hurriedly I scanned the melee, but
with no luck. I couldn't wait for
the ride to finish, so I could
investigate who this man was and
what he wanted from me; but the
ferris wheel was sweeping faster
and faster, it seemed, and I
wasn't sure if I would ever see
that ebony mustache again, or
what I would say if I did.
Each time I circled, the ground
showed no sign of him.
Later, dawdling down the
fairway, stuffing cotton candy in
my face, which gave me a pink
mustache, he appeared in the
doorway of a display. The cane
flashed in the sun as the man
With the ebony mustache
stretched the canvas high above
me so that I might pass before
him into the tent.
I saw a crowd of people
shuffling through hay, looking
into stalls; muffled sounds of
horses or maybe baboons
were projected towards me
through the din of the gay
crowd.
Was I being solicited or merely
entertained? This had become all
too curious—I decided to stride
well ahead of my guide, and
snaked through all the
pandemonium of a political
convention and toward the
corner booth. On a tasteful
platform, there were albino
siamese twins, a delightful pair,
Sipping tea. Chattily, they
Whispered completely
undisturbed by the taunts flung
at them by a gang of suckling
boys. I felt the cane press the
small of my back.
"They love the Haydn, the
tea's for free, and for two
hundred bucks they couldn't
turn it down. Look what else I
have here my boy."
I whirled to face him. "Show
Your hand, you seem to think
You're dealer here," I demanded,
not appreciating his pointed
introduction.
"I have a goat boy who eats
too much hay, my fish woman
needs her tank cleaned; the grey
haired boy in the center smokes
too many cigars. You know they
formed a union today. Sport, the
skeleton of the Java woman cost
me a fortune in the bidding war
With, the museum and the plane
fare for the gorilla man with the
bluest hair in the northern
hemisphere cost me a fortune.
But I have a space for you."

Presenting Baltimore City Fair
By GAYLE COHEN
More than two million persons
will get together this weekend to
have fun and pay tribute to
Baltimore. The occasion is the
seventh annual Baltimore City
Fair, which begins today and
runs through Sunday night.
The festivities take place just
west of the newly-refurbished
Inner Harbor, with the port and
the downtown business district
acting as a scenic backdrop.
Entertainment will be
provided nonstop on each of the
fair's five stages. Headliners
include singer Joe Williams at 8
p.m. Friday, bandleader Benny
Goodman at 8 p.m. Saturday,
and drummer Buddy Rich at 8
p.m. Sunday. Specialty acts will
be presented on the
country-western, ethnic, and
children's stages.
The food selection will also
run the gamut from the
traditional standbys to the wildly
exotic. Several ethnic
organizations will sell native
delicacies, and the conventional
Maryland crabcakes and beer will
abound.
Despite its loose appearance,
the fair serves a serious purpose.
As Lannie Taliaserro of the fair's
Coordinating Council explained,
"Our philosophy has always been
to focus on the vitality of
Baltimore as an urban center. It's
the onl fair of its kind, and it

was brought into being to point
up that Baltimore is not dead."
In keeping with this attitude,
the fair stresses individual arid
community involvement. For
example, almost all of the more
than 7,000 workers are
volunteers. Their dedication
stems from pride in Baltimore
and their neighborhoods.
Randall Shaull, chairman of
the Irvington booth, commented
on the fair's importance. "Since
World War II, the world has been
used to transiency. People just
move. They don't take advantage
of their city. I have to have a
positive viewpoint. If I didn't feel
this way, I wouldn't be in this
business."
Shaull's booth is only one of
75 neighborhood display stalls

Irvington booth will feature a

section, a residential region in the
southwest. A collage of
photographs will display

historical material. The
important idea, according to

non-commercial, fresh, and
appealing."

Is the wind still blowing:A voice ac/es amid the dead

•

By DAVID HAWK
As every rock magazine from
here to Hibbing has testified, Bob
Dylan is a living legend.
Unfortunately, even such
larger-than-life figures can blow
it, as Tuesday night's Dylan
special (Hard Rain) bears out.
The live performance, taped in
Colorado, was a disappointment,
as even the most fanatical
Dylanite would be forced to
admit.
Although just seeing Dylan live
was a thrill, and even though it
was his first commercial
television special, Dylan's
somewhat tuneless gargling, the
antics of the other members of
the Rolling Thunder Revue, and
the questionable quality of the
music left one unsatisfied.
"A Hard Rain's A-Gonna Fall"
was perhaps the best selection in
the show, and was the first
performed. All the songs would
appeal to hard-core Dylan
people, but one got the
discomforting impression that
they could have and had been
done better. "Idiot Wind", the
final number, was the nadir, as
Dylan slipped into the
monotonous forced singing
which characterizes Before the
Flood. The preceding pieces were
more tunefully done, but these
fell into two categories: the
acoustic songs, on which Dylan
and Baez usually colloborated,
holding the verses to unnatural
lengths while the camera nearly
poked them in the head; and the
more electric versions, on which
the Revue paused while Dylan
fired out a line, and then plunged
back into a pattern of repetitive
and uninspiring accompaniment.
Perhaps the way the songs
were done was excusable, even
though the performance doesn't
compare to Dylan's May 1966
Dublin concert, but TV Guide's
promotional blurb ironically
pointed up Hard Rain's most
important and frustrating
inadequacies. The show was
billed as a portrait of Dylan, a
"multi-faceted view," a
performance demonstrating that
Dylan has justifiably been
interpreted and acclaimed as "a
teacher, revolutionary, firebrand,
messiah, mystic, prophet." The
view was hardly multi-faceted,
unless you term alternation
between two camera angles as
multi-faceted. The show
obsfucated the "real" Dylan, if it
did anything at all in terms ,of a
personal portrait. To pretend
that the performance revealed
Dylan as a prophet, mystic, et
cetera is absurd. What did Hard
Rain accomplish in terms of
explicating Dylan in any sense?
Little if anything. It is extremely
unfortunate that the appearance,
ballyhooed as it was, was so
poorly organized and executed,
and so successful in disguising his
genius.
That Dylan has been one of
the single most important forces
in popular music few will deny.
In the tumultuous sixties, he
captured the spiritual restlessness
of American youth with a force,
vision, and clarity which has
never been equalled.
Unquestionably, this is the key

to his success and the essence of
his brilliance: Dylan is most of all
an emotional genius ("How does
it fe-e-e-e-e-1??"). Despite the
less-than-lustrous quality of his
voice, and his imperfect musical
ability, Dylan has become
famous on the strength of his
knack for articulating the
frustrations, needs, and problems
of his generation.
But the juxtaposition of
Dylan's greatness and his grating
TV-special debut point up what
is probably the most pressing
issue concerning the Voice of the
sixties: Is the Dylan of that
turbulent era merely a pitiful
anachronism in the seventies,
hanging onto a reputation built
ten years ago? Or can the
25-year-old who set the
American consciousness
throbbing with "A Hard Rain's
A-Gonna Fall," "Blowin' in the
Wind," "Like a Rolling Stone,"
and Blonde on Blonde "speak"
again at the hoary age of 35?
Bob Dylan and the nineteen
sixties are inseparable, the mood
and the man so a part of each
other, from the Missile Crisis to
Berkeley ("Who can separate the
dancer from the dance?"). DyIgn
asked the questions that
America's youth felt but could
not articulate ("OH, mama, can
this really be the end. . .?-), and,
avoiding soothing answers, bared
the naked agony of his soul, and
ripped away the veil, standing
unwound beneath the sky on
clouds unbound by law, in a
soldier's stance aiming his hand
at the mongrel dogs who taught.

perhaps feeling too much for too
many, and now he who has
always led the way must decide
whether there is anywhere else to
go.
After the musical brilliance of
the sixties, which was coupled
with a rare sense of social
consciousness, the seventies haye
been marked by a chilling
descent into the sugary
empty-headed optimism of John
Denver and Olivia Newton-John
and the convoluted clanking of
such entries as Led Zeppelin,
Kiss, and the LA. Death Trip,
not to mention the usual top-40
sillylovesongs syndrome. The
Grateful Dead and The Rolling
Stones hang on with nothing left,
and groups like Quicksilver
Messenger Service and the
erstwhile-Jefferson Airplane roll
over in their once-respectable
graves and attempt to fill the gap.
Perhaps Dylan has been caught in
the post-sixties malaise of
mediocrity and big-bucks
strategems, his thought-dreams
disintegrating, his watchtower
left abandoned, as the wind
howling still louder in the
deafening silence, yet unheard.
Money talks, Dylan walks
4L L THAT JAZZ
In the past few years some of the best concerts have been sponsored by the city government. Last year's City Fair
presented Maynard Ferguson, as well as Dave Brubeck and Sons. Last summer's free On Stage Downtown series
included three jazz concerts: Maynard Ferguson, Lionel Hampton, and Charlie Byrd. This year's City Fair (Sept. 17, 18,
19) will have some local jazz groups on the minor stages, but the big concerts are all on Stage One. These concerts are
included in the $1,25 entrance fee to the fairgrounds (Inner Harbor West). Today, Al Baitch is scheduled at 3:30 p.m.,
and Joe Williams at 8 p.m. On Saturday the Jimmy Wells Quintet will play at 4:30 p.m., and Benny Goodman brings
back the memories at 8 p.m. Hank Levy's Towson State Jazz Ensemble will perform on Sunday at 3p.m., with Buddy
Rich scheduled to play at 8 p.m.

But the sixties are gone
forever, the times are not
changing as they once were, and
disillusionment no longer has
even poignance. With the end of
the decade came the end of
Dylan's vision, or so it would
seem. John Wesley Harding,
which came out in January of
1968, appears to mark the end of
Dylan's most brilliant periods.
Excluding the official release of
The Basement Tapes in the
summer of 1975, ten Dylan
albums have been released since
John Wesley Harding, and even
the best of these cannot come up
to his previous work. The
urgency is gone, an intangible has
been lost, and even though Dylan
addicts don't know how to quit,
there must lurk for them the fear
that he in some sense has.
Now it looks as if Dylan is
going on, writing good music
where he once wrote great music,
building a ten million dollar
mansion in California, replacing
the aesthetics of vision with the
economics of self-enrichment.
Dylan said one time that he
would rather die than decay. In a
recent TV Guide interview he
claimed that he is writing new
music, trying new things.
However, the suspicion is that
Dylan is indeed decaying. No,
maybe he was right—maybe he's
already dead.
In any case, Dylan's position
has never been an easy one. He
went through the harassment and
scrutiny which accompany being
acclaimed as a seer, he
experienced the excruciation of

The sun also looms on other horizons

College. To many Hopkins males,
the memory, or anticipation, of
such a sight connotes the glories
of a one-night conquest, or
Perhaps a lasting undergraduate
affair.
To me, sun rising over
Goucher College was a sight I
could barely see, for the sunlight
burst so glaringly through the
windows that it blinded me
Whenever I looked outside. It was
eight a.m. on a December
morning last winter. I sat quietly
in the Goucher Library, intently
Porin g over Smirnitsky's

of

n minous, by virtue of its

Of course, I hadn't timed my
departure at all with the shuttle
leaving Goucher. A vacant face in

So I lumbered back to Van
Meter, sat out on the steps for
twenty-five minutec, and froze. It
never occurred to me to wait
inside.
The semester dragged on for
another four days, with two
all-nighters. I then made a quick
escape to New York City.
Of six grades, four were
test -case borderline. They all
went the right way; I made the
Dean's List.
Next term, the apathy
increased. "Getting by" now
consisted of attending classes on
an intermittent basis, and living
in a room that was decorated
early- Armageddon.
My need for some form of an
active existence was quickly
sated with the development of a
few intriguing personal
relationships. There was a vivid
sense within me that I should
somehow go beyond that, but I
lacked the motivation, or
possibly the fortitude, to do so.
Controversies
On campus, controversies
raged. I signed a petition
protesting the honorary degree
bestowed upon the Princess
Ashraf of Iran, and donated fifty
cents for the privilege of wearing
a bracelet which celebrated the
cause of one Iranian political
prisoner. Within the day, the
sweat on my wrist had caused the
ink to run. The legibility of the
inscription dissolved, and with it
any fleeting personal sense of
.social awareness.
In late January, prior to the
Ashraf incident, the editor of the
News-Letter began pestering me
to write a major feature on
Hopkins' takeover of the
Baltimorean Hotel. What was
wanted was a human interest
nerloot

town-gown situation. Recent
editorials in the News-Letter had
come out strongly against
University expansion.
Myself, among others, doubted
the feasibility of this story as a
feature—whether it was there to
be written.
Yet it was a week in which I
could think of nothing better to
do. I took the story. It occurred
to me that I might end up almost
having to invent angles. But my
frame of mind had evolved to the
point where such idealistic goals
as "total journalistic integrity"
seemed irrelevant in terms of
pursuable or desirable
achievements.
The feature that I wrote on
the Baltimorean did not contain
one single untruth, misquotation,
or any other overt indication of
spurious journalism. What it did
contain was a series of
manipulated scenes, and
conversations that were
consciously overblown and
underblown to suit the tone of
the article. Of greatest
consequence were an elderly
switchboard operator who
divided her attention equally
between myself and the ABC late
night special, and my next door
neighbor (I live right near the
Baltimorean), who was just full
of quotable truisms about
"longhairs" from Hopkins, and
how they hurt the neighborhood.
Suffice it to say that I wrote an
article which, however imperfect
stylistically, provided excellent
fodder for an "outraged"
editorial decrying Hopkins'
repeated violations of the
surrounding community.
None of which bothered me.
My own view of the situation was
passively pragmatic. I saw
Hopkins as the heavyweight, who
had the sheer brute strength to
beat up on the lightweight
community organizations
virtually at will. I also perceived
such bullying tactics as
essentially a mistake, and any
positive steps taken to improve
town-gown relations (which was

being done at the time) as being
highly desirable. My thinking was
that eventually Hopkins was
going to encounter a situation
that necessitated some form of
University expansion, over which
the community had total veto
power, by virtue of a strict
zoning law, or the like. And if at
that time the Greater Homewood
Community Corporation had
experienced nothing but being
pushed around,they would never
give in.
I saw nothing inherently venal
in the purchase of the
Baltimorean, which had been
obtained for the purpose of
housing graduate studentc
nudged out of McCoy by
undergraduates. But to the
extent that the property had
been usurped from the
community, and not bargained
for, the operation had been a
diplomatic blunder.
So what? My opinion. Never
expressed in the feature, and so
of no consequence. After all, I
had written the story they had
told me to write. I had gotten by.
That's all that matters. Right?
Then Faulkner (a la A Rose
For Emily) came to North
Charles Street. A fifty year old
woman named Ann Baker had
been living in near-total seclusion
for thirteen years, seen only by
her priest and by a delivery man
from the Greenway Pharmacy.
She was a recluse, living only
with room-high piles of garbage.
And she didn't want to leave. So
when she was told that she had
to go, she feigned acquiensence,
and then lit the garbage with a
match. And Ann Baker died.
The next day the News-Letter
came out with a lead article on
Ann Baker's death accompanied
by an angry, vindictive editorial.
The pieces combined to imply
one simple statement: Hopkins
killed Ann Baker.
I was stunned. The conclusion
was specious. For this reason:
Ann Baker predetermined her
own death. Thirteen years
before, she had carefully begun

to construct an existence which
could never have tolerated
exposure to the external world.
Hopkins' eviction did force the
crisis, and so the suicide (her one
alternative for an absolute
rebellion against reality). But the
crisis probably would have been
forced anyway, by some other
agency, because THE
BALTIMOREAN WAS FOR
SALE. It is a definite possibility
that WHOEVER had bought that
building might have evicted Ann
Baker. And so killed her?
One can only guess at the
reasoning of the News-Letter
staff. It seems legitimate to say,
however, that the Ann Baker
editorial was • just a natural
consequence of the continuing
series of articles and editorials
concerning the Baltimorean. And
the longest, and perhaps most
widely read of those articles. ..
I wrote.
And hadn't believed in.
And had written anyway.
Just to get by.
In righteous anger, I decided
to fire off an angry response to
the editors. I never did.
Since then, the issue has died,
in a manner somewhat quieter
than the death of Ann Baker.
To me, however, there is a
different issue, one that has little
to do with Hopkins housing,
town-gown politics, or whatever.
It is an issue which has not died
in my mind.
The issue is the reconstruction
of one's frame of mind, to the
point where it can be resolved:
" I will not spend this life
'getting by."
The issue is the need to
awaken to what is around you. If
the Hopkins existence is to be a
legitimate one,it cannot be spent
ignoring three-quarters of the
university because, "Why should
I care. . .", "I don't fit in with
that. ..","Those people couldn't
care about me. ..","The girls on
this campus are too obnoxious. .
.", "The boys on this campus
can't accept intelligent women. .
.", "Yeah, philosophy's
rnterestmg, but it's bullshit, and
besides it won't help me get into
med school..."
Forfeit
How many have loved physics,
but no longer think about it,just
blindly take notes and memorize,
just to get by? How many never
listen to a professor who actually
has something to say, or worse
yet, don't even make an effort to
take courses with those
professors?
How many have spent most of
their career at Hopkins
consciously forfeiting the
opportunity to learn?
The school year has begun
once more, my third year ai
Hopkins. For the first time, I am
awake. I make an effort, perhaps
visibly the effort of a neophyte,
to communicate with individuals
throughout the Hopkins
spectrum (and beyond), to
experience, to soak in, to try to
understand, to reach a critical
comprehension of, all that I see.
And I try to see as much as I can.
To the extent that I have
achieved these goals so far, the
question, "Where is my life
going?" no longer grates on my
soul.
In the morning the sun rises

mao
Last night approximately one hundred people
gathered in
the Clipper Room of Shriver Hall to participate.in a memorial
service for the great, fallen Chinese leader, Chairman
Mao
Tse-Tung. At the service, Mao, who died last week at the
age
of 82, was the subject of numerous tributes and
expressions
of admiration and thanks for the tremendous
revolutionary
change through which he helped guide the Chinese people
in
the last sixty years.
A central feature of Mao's life was his
constant,
unwavering dedication to serving his Chinese countryme
n.
Theoretician, statesman, military leader, and educator were
but some of the forms this service took. Although the
has been long, difficult and not without mistakes, road
even
Western observers must admit that the quality of life in
China
has been dramatically upgraded under Mao's leadershi
.

But in the end, Mao wanted to be remembered primarily as
a teacher. Perhaps more than any other modern figure, Mao
was able to communicate a dynamic, integrated
understanding of how the world works and how people can
change it. While most of his theories and accomplishments
run counter to the American ethic, they are well worth
considering in light of the tremendous influence they have
exerted on people throughout the world. And perhaps more
than anything else, Mao should be bailed for illustrating that
a betterment of the human condition need not be an idle,
utopian dream, but, through a common, sustained effort, can
become gratifying reality.

Captain Bligh

The University:for whose end?
We need a sense of morality
By MARK HERTSGAARD
"What is this university supposed to
be?"
After more than a week of
"orientation", the same conversations
(where you from, what's your major,
what are you taking, etc.), and official
welcomes from university luminaries
of various intensities, that question, or
variations of it, has probably been
pondered by many a freshman.
Although perhaps to a lesser extent,
upperclassmen may be considering the
same query as they come progressively
closer to graduation. Seniors can
hardly avoid the matter since
everyone they talk to asks the
inevitable question regarding their
plans after leaving Hopkins. Of course,
the answer depends largely on what a
senior has already done at this
university and how well it has met
his/her needs.
At the root of most of the
challenges against the traditionalist
view of the university has been the
disturbing realization that a college
education no longer assures a
good
job" in today's society. In her book,
The Case Against College, Caroline
Bird argues that many high school
graduates can fare better financially
by going to work and saving the
thousands of would-be tuition dollars.
In the face of such criticism. Johns
Hopkins President Steven Muller has
called for the goals of American
universities to be reoriented toward
higher learning and away from mere
higher skilling. While preparation for
future jobs would still remain a
fixture of the college years, the
primary purpose of university
instruction and study must be to
produce graduates who are highly
educated.
Of course, the role of the university
is always partly determined by the
constraints of the society in which it
exists. The purposes of universities in
1976 America differ markedly from
those of colonial times when
institutions of higher education
produced mainly clergy and teachers.
Colleges and universities by and large
remained establishments reserved for
the intellectually and socially elite
well into the tweatieth century. But
around the time of World Vvar II, and
corresponding to the ever increasing
needs for educated, technical
personnel to run the rapidly
developing American economy, higher
education began to be democratized.
The numbers of college students and,
consequently, also their diversity in
terms of race and class,nottceably
increased. The university began to be
perceived as an institution that
pumped out the graduates necessary
to keep America moving forward in
the modern age.

As Alvin Toffler wrote in Future
Shock, "Mass education was the
ingenious machine constructed by
industrialism to produce the kind of
adults it needed to run industrial
society. . .Yet the whole idea of
assembling masses of students (raw
material) to be processed by teachers
(workers) in a centrally located school
(factory) was a stroke of industrial
genius." Although Toffler was writing
in regard to the time period of the
Industrial Revolution, the parallels to
today are obvious. In fact, much of
the student protest of the 1960's was
directed against the regimentation,
alienation and authoritarianism of
higher education and the society
which it reflected.
Now, as we move through the
1970's, it is more common for
students to question the purposes of
higher education in more
self-centered, career oriented terms.
Will it give me a better job? Is it worth
all that money?
It is exceedingly important for us
to remember that views on the
purpose and the role of the university
greatly depend on one's perspective
on and relationship to it. Rest assured
that a rising student politico's and a
pre-med's views differ substantially
and that their difference is small when
compared to that between a staff
custodian and a university trustee.
Consider als9 the contrast between
how major corporations and
community residents conceive of
universities and their members.
In spite of these individual
differences, the world of academia is
still permeated by the comfortable.
conventional view of the role of the
university. The university is seen as a
center of culture, free thinking and
independent, oective research and
instruction. The uni•
:s
sometimes considered to
„ sort of
enlightened, benevolent servant who
earns his keep in society by helping us
better to understand and confront the
world and by tackling the tough
problems that impede human
progress.
In judging the aptness of this
description, two suggestions may
prove helpful. First, in making any
social judgment, perhaps the most
useful questions to ask are: who is
hurt, who is helped, how, and why?
Second, the judgments again depend
largely on whose perspective (e.g.,
student, faculty or society) is
considered.
For the well-directed, career
oriented undergrad, Johns Hopkins
provides one of the finest educations
in the country; that is, the JHU
education will help its recipient along
the road to grad school, a respectable,
and perhaps even interesting, job, and
ultimately to American success. But
before lauding Hopkins on this
accomplishment, we must consider
the nature of this success. In this
context, success can be seen as
implying the wealth, prestige and
security that usually accompany
upper middle class existence. But
what about the notion of service to
society? Is an M.D. degree to be
viewed as an unofficial license to print
money or rather as an opportunity to
serve society in a special capacity?
While students participate almost
exclusively in the second of the
university's major functions, as the
recipients of teaching, professors
engage in both teaching and research.
At Hopkins, the professors most
esteemed by the university are those
who bring fame and prestige (and,
therefore, plenty of research funds) to
Hopkins; i.e., the well renowned
research scholars. Some of these men
and women are also fine, dedicated
educators, a happy combination for
all concerned. Some are not. But for
those faculty members who do not
excel in the "publish of perish" game,
receiving tenure is almost impossible if
he/she is judged by colleagues in the
academic world not to be in the top
twenty percent in his/her field. This
priority of research over teaching
clearly has negative ramifications on
the quality of instruction at Hopkins.

But we must probe beyond these
ramifications to try to determine what
this priority says about the nature of
Johns Hopkins and other universities.
It indicates that the primary allegiance
of the university and many of its
faculty must be toward the kind of
research that will attract substantial
grant monies. A research project or an
innovative program cannot be run if
no funds are available. And what kind
of research fits this definition? Often,
and obviously, it must be the kind
that will serve those wealthy and
powerful interests (big corporations,
the government, etc.) who can afford
to sponsor it. This should not be seen
as surprising. How reasonable is it to
expect that profit-conscious
organizations will squander money on
research that is of little or no use to
them?
These practices and relationships
have very definite implications on
how and who the university serves in
its cotnmunity and society. To
continue to exist, a primary concern
of Johns Hopkins and other
universities must be to stay in the
good graces of the rich and powerful.
The conducting of research that serves
those interests is a major, but not the
only, tool at the disposal of a
university. These priorities, which
dictate that much of the research in
American universities be oriented
toward such areas as weapons
development rather than projects that
will help those most in need, are
similar to those that cause the
government to spend a
disproportionate amount of national
defense at the expense of rural health
services. The challenging by
universities of this "them that has.
gits" status quo is not encouraged.
This is not meant to imply that a
university performs no useful
functions. Nor should one get the
impression that university, corporate
and governmental officials spend all
their waking hours plotting to exploit
the poor. Such ‘Tiotild be an
insensitive, shallow and naive
judgement. Qn the contrary, there are
many instances when useful services
have been performed by people within
the university. I3ut in aggregate, no

mistaken judgement can be made. A
university cannot serve two masters
and, when forced to choose, cannot
afford to bite the hand that feeds it.
Some may counter this line of
reasoning with the argument (often
heard during last year's Iranian
demonstrations) that a university
must play this unfortunate game if it
is to remain solvent. That's the way
the system is, the way the world
operates. If the university is to exist
and hope to serve society, it must
sometimes accept money for some
research activities that are ethically
questionable. Such people sometimes
even admit that this practice cheapens
the integrity of the university, but
would consider it to be a necessary
evil that is traded off against the good
that the urliversity can do. This
counter-argument is correct in one
very important point—yes, the system,
the constraints of modern, Western
society, does demand that universities
perform this way. However, this
argument errs by limply accepting
these practices as regrettable
necessities rather than questioning the
morality and legitimacy of the system
that produces them.

The 1977-78 competition for grants
for graduate study abroad offered
under the Mutual Educational
Exchange Program (Fulbright-Hays).
and by foreign governments,
universities and private donors will

Booters impressive in GW loss
By ANDREW COHEN
Plagued by three key offensive
injuries, the Johns Hopkins
soccer team was blanked, 1-0, by
a strong team from George
Washington University in their
final preseason clash.
The only goal of the game
came late in the first half when a
Blue Jay penalty allowed George
Washington to cash in on a direct
kick.
Although they lost, the Blue
Jay squad looked very impressive
on defense against the well
disciplined offense of GW. The
opponent maintained excellent
ball control throughout the
game, thereby calling the Jay's
defense to meet the challenge.
In the first half a George
Washington break away was
halted by the quick hands of a
.11-1U fullback who pulled down
the potential scorer. When the
oPponent failed on the penalty
oPportunity the Blue Jays were
out of trouble. Later in the
second half it was goalie Ken
Suesse who stopped a GW threat
by just tipping away another
beautifully placed direct kick.
With the big opening game
against Haverford only a few
days away, Coach Bob Oliver
thought it wise to rest his starting
offensive line trio of Greg
C unningham, Larry
McGowan,

and Hyam Levin. Without this
extra scoring punch in the lineup
it was difficult for the JHUers to
generate any offensive threats,
though they did muster a few.
About a quarter of the way
into the second half the Blue
Jays were able to put pressure on
the George Washington goal
tender. Some unnecessary
dramatics on the part of the GW
goalie allowed the ball to squirt
loose in front of the net and if it
hadn't been for the experienced
feet of the GW defenders, the
Jays would have found
themselves right back in the
ballgame.
On another occasion lineman
Joe Siemek was able to gain
control of the loose ball and send
a looping shot right on net. The
GW goalie was able to recover
just in time in order to bat away
the potential goal.
JHU's last scoring opportunity
came with only seconds left in
the game. Gary Ignatowski was
fed a beautiful slide pass that left
him ten yards out, one on one
against the goalie. But again the
Jays were turned away by a
pretty save.
Coach Oliver was pleased with
this final game as he was with the
entire soccer preseason.
According to him his entire
substitution bench showed poise
